items.title: Comparing test assertion styles in JavaScript
items.content:
#â€‹657 â€” October 5, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

An Interactive Intro to CRDTs â€” Conflict-free replicated data types (the so-called CRDTs) provide a popular approach to replicate data across numerous clients and allow live collaboration between them without conflicts. This post really digs into what makes CRDTs tick well, complete with interactiveÂ examples.

Jake Lazaroff

Test Assertion Styles in JavaScript â€” Isaac, fundamental to the development of npm and the growth of Node, shares his thoughts on the two main approaches common in JavaScript testing APIs and which he prefersÂ best.

Isaac Z. Schlueter

Free Course: Land a Software Engineering Role â€” Jerome Hardaway has helps over 300 folks get a software development job â€” now he shares his advice in this video course â€” featuring resume tips, networking advice, how to optimize your GitHub profile for technical scrutiny, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

  • ğŸ”µ TypeScript 5.3 beta has been released with improved support for import attributes, improved type narrowing in numerous situations, and inlay hints in VS Code can now jump you to the type's definition.

  • ğŸ” npm provenance is now generally available on the main npm registry. Here's a live example.

  • ğŸ¨ Adobe officially launched its version of Photoshop for the Web last week and Addy Osmani wrote a great post showing off all the web technologies it took to make it happen. The modern browser is a powerhouse!

  • ğŸ  In June we featured val.town, an interesting site where you can write and deploy TypeScript in a social and serverless fashion. Big changes are coming in the shape of Val Town v3. A platform to watch.

  • ğŸ¤” Was JavaScript really made in 10 days? It's complicated.

  • âš ï¸ The forthcoming ESLint 9.0 is a significant enough release that you might want to prepare your custom rules for it in advance.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • Node v20.8.0 (Current) â€“ Key performance improvements for streams.

  • Sinon 16.1 â€“ Provides test spies, stubs and mocks.

  • Astro 3.2, Redux Toolkit 1.9.7, and pnpm 8.8

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

'Strong Static Typing, A Hill I'm Willing to Die On...' â€” Starting off with TypeScript and moving on to Rust, the author shares why he feels so strongly that when it comes to having static types in a language, there really is no argument. (This then led to extensive discussion on HackerÂ News.)

Tom Hacohen

ğŸ“— Â The Story of Third-Party JavaScript (The Book) â€” Manning published a book by Ben Vinegar and Anton Kovalyov ten years ago that was entirely focused on writing JavaScript to run on other peopleâ€™s sites â€“Â quite apt as the authors worked at Disqus at the time! This post isnâ€™t about the topic itself but goes deep into how the book came together and how well itÂ did.

Ben Vinegar

ğŸ“… Â JetBrains JavaScript Day 2023: A Virtual Event You Wonâ€™t Want toÂ Miss â€” Get up to speed with modern JavaScript and TypeScript development in just oneÂ day.

JetBrains sponsor

Working with a TypeScript Monorepo with npm Workspaces â€” npmâ€™s workspaces feature makes it easier to manage multiple packages within a single top-levelÂ package/monorepo.

Dmitry Kudryavtsev

Test Your React Libraries Locally with Yalc â€” Yalc simplifies the process of working with and â€˜publishingâ€™ packages entirely locally so you can try things out without publishing to a remote, and potentially public, registry.

Andrew Israel (PropelAuth Blog)

â–¶Â Â Let's Create a Filter Table Component in Vue
Andrew Schmelyun

Integrating Slonik with Express.js â€” A type-safe Postgres client library.
Gajus Kuizinas

Next.js 13 vs Remix: A Case Study
Prateek Surana

Using the Intl Segmenter API
Kilian Valkhof

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Tailwind Elements 1.0: 500+ Bootstrap Components Recreated withÂ Tailwind â€” Claims to offer more functionality compared to Bootstrap and follows a 'minimal' Material-esque design language for user familiarity. Easily integrates with Angular, Vue, etc.

Tailwind Elements

Lite YouTube Embed 0.3: A Faster Youtube Embed â€” Faster than the official one, at least. v0.3 implements reliable autoplay. Thereâ€™s a live demoÂ here.

Paul Irish

Day.js: A 2KB Immutable Date Library â€” Pitched as a Moment.js alternative with a mostly compatible API, Day is a smaller library for parsing, validating, manipulating, and displaying dates andÂ times.

iamkun

Stop Feeling Lost and Inefficient When Debugging via console.log â€” See console.log output and runtime errors alongside your code. No config, no setup, no hassle. Supports Vite, Bun, Webpack, Next.js, Remix, andÂ more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Viselect: Let Users Visually Select DOM Elements â€” If youâ€™ve got a variety of elements and you want users to be able to select them in groups, individually, or even in multiple groups, this lets you offer that functionality easily. Can be used in a vanilla fashion or with integrations for React orÂ Vue.js.

Simon Reinisch

Tailwind Next.js Starter Blog 2.0: A Starter Template for a Next.js Blog â€” An up-to-date template using the modern Next.js app directory structure along with server components. A full explanation of the updates.

Timothy Lin

Kaluma: A Tiny JS Runtime for the Raspberry Pi Pico â€” Can you get a JavaScript runtime into the 64KB necessary to run on the Raspberry Pi Pico (which uses the RP2040 microcontroller)? KalumaÂ can.

Kaluma Project

sort-on 6.0: Sort Arrays on an Object Property â€” Short & sweet. Samples.

Sindre Sorhus

Craft.js 0.2: A React Framework for Building Drag and Drop PageÂ Editors â€” Itâ€™s a bold move to make the landing page for your project be a text editor itself, but we like it. GitHubÂ repo.

Prev Wong

Create Collaborative Apps Like Figma and Miro in Days with Ably

Ably sponsor

  • ğŸ“… React Native Big Calendar 4.3 â€“ A Google Calendar/Outlook-style large calendarÂ control.

  • ğŸ“Š Lightweight Charts 4.1 â€“ High performance financial charting for canvases. Release notes.

  • CKEditor5 40.0 â€“ Commercial rich text editor framework. Now with an AI assistant feature.

  • article-extractor 8.0 â€“ Extract article content for a URL inÂ Node.

  • Shaka Player 4.5 â€“ Library to play adaptive media formats (DASH, HLS and MSS).

  • Ziggy 1.7 â€“ Use Laravel named routes inÂ JavaScript.

  • Marked 9.1 â€“ Markdown parser & compiler.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Apply Now and Work #LikeABosch â€” Our promise to our associates is rock-solid: we grow together, enjoy our work & inspire each other. Join in & feel theÂ difference.
Bosch

Frontend Developer ğŸš€ (Remote, Work from Anywhere ğŸ–ï¸) â€” Enjoy TypeScript, React, GraphQL and performance? Join in building our super-fast headless commerce service with a beautifulÂ UI.
Crystallize

ğŸÂ A VS Code Bonus

Awesome VS Code: A Curated List of Themes and Extensions â€” Yep, itâ€™s one of those â€˜awesomeâ€™ lists, but it's packed not only with links to themes and useful extensions, but it has screenshots for most of them too. Skim through, something will jump out atÂ you.

Valerii Iatsko

items.title: Getting some closure
items.content:
#â€‹656 â€” September 28, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The Saga of Google's Closure Compiler â€” Dan looks back at Googleâ€™s Closure Compiler, a JavaScript transpiler Google built in 2004 and used most heavily in the pre-TypeScript era to reduce the size of JavaScript files, check types, and otherwise handle common pitfalls. A neat bit of JavaScriptÂ history.

Dan Vanderkam

Speeding up the JavaScript Ecosystem: Polyfills Gone Rogue â€” Marvin's mission to speed up popular libraries continues. First blogging on the topic last year, now heâ€™s looking at the role polyfills play in making packages large and inefficient. There are two sides to every story, though, as this Hacker News threadÂ found.

Marvin Hagemeister

Building Cross-Platform Desktop Apps withÂ Electron â€” In this detailed video course Steve Kinney shares how to build robust, user-friendly Electron-based desktop apps, covering key concepts like main and renderer processes, inter-process communication, security, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¦ TC39 met earlier today and advanced several proposals including RegExp escaping and resizable ArrayBuffers (and nixed two, including Symbol.thenable).

  • If possible, please take the State of HTML 2023 survey. Your answers could help determine what features browsers focus on next! And if you don't believe me, let Lea Verou convince you.

  • Verticalize introduces a vertical pipe-like function to JavaScript to help you chain operations together in a more visually appealing way, but.. it's certainly a matter of taste.

  • The Preact team has an update on Preact Signals, their take on reactive programming.

  • Engineers from Vercel and Cloudflare have published a draft spec for a Sockets API for non-browser runtimes. Here's why this all matters.

  • ğŸ“± Strada is a new library from 37signals that bridges the gap between server-rendered HTML and native controls in hybrid mobile apps. Here's how it looks in practice.

  • Publishing packages with npm provenance is now generally available.

  • Cloudflare Workers is a popular serverless platform for running JavaScript functions at the edge and it now has an all new pricing model that's certainly a lot more appealing.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • Shoelace 2.9 â€“ Suite of framework agnostic components. Changelog.

  • Dependency Cruiser 14.0 â€“ Visualize & validateÂ dependencies.

  • Ember 5.3, pnpm 8.8, and Bit 1.0.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

One Thing Nobody Explained To You About TypeScript â€” The author makes a strong case for creating a separate tsconfig.json for each environment your code runs in: â€œToday, I write about one thing about configuring TypeScript that took me years to realize. Iâ€™m sure youâ€™re making the same mistake as IÂ did.â€

Artem Zakharchenko

Upgrading Frontend Dependencies with Confidence â€” Writing tests for logic in our apps is easy, but how can you determine if a component isn't rendering properly? Visual regression testing. Here's a workflow based on GitHub Actions, Playwright, andÂ Argos.

SÃ©bastien Lorber

React Authentication â€” Without Complexity â€” Userfront streamlines authentication & access control so engineers can focus on their core business. Read the docsÂ now.

Userfront sponsor

Understanding the Modulo % Operator â€” Tackles the oft misunderstood operator in Josh's visual, beginner-friendlyÂ style.

Josh W Comeau

â± Â Why the Temporal API is Awesome â€” Itâ€™s still a stage 3 proposal, but the Temporal API works around some of Dateâ€™s limitations without third-partyÂ libraries.

Taro Dragan

Drawing on Google Maps with Drawing Manager â€” A particularly thorough, code-rich followup to Integrating Google Maps inÂ React.

Pavlo Chabanenko (Sudolabs)

Thoughts on Svelte 5 as a 3+ Year Full-Time SvelteÂ Dev â€” Thoughts that lead to the proposal of Pelte, an attempt to spark conversation rather than a real tool (so far).

Filip Tangen

The Forecast For Your Next Database: Strongly Typed andÂ Cloudy

EdgeDB sponsor

Building Token Based Authentication with JWTs on Fastify
Arif Imran

The Angular Renaissance: Why Frontend Devs Should Revisit It
Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

How React Server Components Made Our Site Faster
Christian Mathiesen (Frigade)

Replacing RxJS with a State Machine
Ben Nadel

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Tesseract.js 5.0: JavaScript OCR for 100+ Languages â€” A port of the C++-based Tesseract library used to extract text from images. v5.0 is a big deal as there are huge file size reductions resulting in a 50% decrease in runtime size, a similar reduction in memory use, and iOS 17 compatiblity. GitHubÂ repo.

Tesseract Team

ChatGPT.js: A Library for Working with ChatGPT via theÂ DOM â€” Includes a fairly extensive API that lets you interact with ChatGPT for use in Chrome extensions, Tampermonkey scripts, and soÂ on.

KudoAI

Industry-Leading JavaScript Components for the Web â€” Build your apps with powerful JavaScript developer tools including reporting solutions, spreadsheets, and UIÂ components.

GrapeCity sponsor

Instant.dev: A New Postgres-Focused ORM for JavaScript â€” Aims to introduce a more Ruby on Rails/Active Record-style experience to the increasingly rich JavaScript ORMÂ ecosystem.

instantâ€¤dev

Chardet 2.0: Character Encoding Detection Library â€” It uses statistical methods to determine the most likely encoding of a supplied buffer, string, or file, from a selection of aboutÂ 30.

Dmitry Shirokov

ğŸ‘¾ Â n64js: A Nintendo 64 Emulator in JavaScript â€” Thereâ€™s a Web-based version to try (if you have the right files) or just â–¶ï¸ watch aÂ video.

Paul Holden

  • ğŸ—“ React Chrono 2.3 â€“ Timeline component. SomeÂ examples.

  • ip-address 9.0 â€“ Parse & manipulate IPv4/6Â addresses.

  • Sonner 1.0 â€“ Toast notifications React component.

  • Jazzer.js 2.0 â€“ In-process fuzzing for Node.js.

  • JZZ 1.7 â€“ MIDI library for Node and browsers.

  • Preact 10.18.0

  • esbuild 0.19.4

ğŸ’» Jobs

Frontend Developer ğŸš€ (Remote, Work from Anywhere ğŸ–ï¸) â€” Enjoy TypeScript, React, GraphQL and performance? Join in building our super-fast headless commerce service with a beautifulÂ UI.
Crystallize

Full-Stack Engineer, Remote in EU or Berlin â€” Join our small team to build an insurance product that people love. We use React, TypeScript, Prisma, NestJS andÂ more.
Feather

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ•¹Â The hardest JavaScript game ever?

JS Crush: Match Values That Are Equal in JS â€” The authorâ€™s comment that this is â€œa game that mocks JS equality quirks, the most absurd feature of the languageâ€ should put you in the right frame of mind for giving this Candy Crush-inspired casual game aÂ go!

Herrington Darkholme

P.S. I'm encountering folks who haven't heard about the â–¶ï¸ TypeScript Origins documentary we featured last week, so I wanted to mention it again in case you have the time spare. I enjoyed it and learned a lot too.

JS Crush: Match Values That Are Equal in JS â€” The authorâ€™s comment that this is â€œa game that mocks JS equality quirks, the most absurd feature of the languageâ€ should put you in the right frame of mind for giving this Candy Crush-inspired casual game aÂ go!
Herrington Darkholme 




P.S. I'm encountering folks who haven't heard about the â–¶ï¸ TypeScript Origins documentary we featured last week, so I wanted to mention it again in case you have the time spare. I enjoyed it and learned a lot too.

items.title: Microsoft spills the tea on TypeScript
items.content:
#â€‹655 â€” September 21, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

â–¶Â Â TypeScript Origins: The Documentary â€” You know youâ€™ve made it when you get your own documentary! This has just dropped but is well produced, packed with stories from TypeScriptâ€™s co-creators, users, and other folks at Microsoft, and kept me entertained. It goes particularly deep into the motivations and process behind TypeScript's creation, including why Microsoft felt it was worth pursuing atÂ all.

OfferZen Origins

ğŸ”¥ The takes get spicer 25+ minutes in as various TypeScript users chip in with their opinions, and even Daniel Rosenwasser, now program manager of the TypeScript team, says he initially worried that Microsoft might "f**k it all up." ğŸ˜… Ryan Dahl pops up about an hour in too.. so I hope you've got some time spare.

Patterns for Reactivity with Modern Vanilla JavaScript â€” When data changes, you often want to do things, and the process that makes that happen is reactivity. While many libraries or frameworks like React or Vue offer reactive solutions out of the box, you can do it all with vanilla JavaScript too, and this post digs into many of the patterns you might need to use, complete withÂ examples.

Marc Grabanski

Handsontable: Data Grid With Spreadsheet Superpowers â€” There are a lot of JavaScript data grids out there, but none are quite like Handsontable. Its Excel-like design, keyboard shortcuts, and navigation make it the perfect tool forÂ developers.

Handsontable sponsor

Deno 1.37: Modern JavaScript in Jupyter Notebooks â€” Not content to let Bun take all the headlines, Deno has come up with something pretty neat here. Deno 1.37 ships with a Jupyter Notebook integration so you can create interactive REPL sessions but using the JavaScript you know and love, rather thanÂ Python.

The Deno Team

JavaScript Minification Benchmarks â€” A frequently updated benchmark suite and results comparing the speed and quality of JavaScript minification across a variety of tools including esbuild, Babel, Bun, SWC, andÂ Uglify.

Hiroki Osame

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • The Svelte team offers a sneak peek at the forthcoming Svelte 5 and introduces the idea of 'runes': "Like every other framework, we've come to the realisation that Knockout was right all along."

  • Happy 27th birthday to JScript! JScript was a version of JavaScript that Microsoft put into IE 3.0 primarily to avoid trademark issues around the name of JavaScript. No-one cares much about that anymore, despite Oracle still technically holding the JavaScript trademark.

  • Folks are discussing whether Node.js needs a mascot of its own.

  • Want to support anyone doing great work on JavaScript projects? You can nominate them for a GitHub Star.

  • If you rely upon the npm package download counts at all, the daily counts for all packages was zero on September 13 and 14 (example). Why? "This issue remains under investigation," says npm support.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • Remix v2 â€“ Popular full stack web framework.

  • Bun 1.0.2 â€“ Bugfixes, faster bun --watch, it now uses V8's Date parser, and Fastify apps now workÂ too.

  • Node.js v20.7 (Current) â€“ Multiple --env-files now supported.

  • Next.js 13.5 â€“ Faster, faster, faster.

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Getting Network Activity Under Control with Priority Hints â€” A look at how browsers can prioritize the loading of resources, how you can explicitly specify a priority when using fetch, and how different ways of loading scripts areÂ prioritized.

Alex MacArthur

Securing Node Apps by Analyzing Real Command Injection Examples â€” When code can be manipulated to run unintended, arbitrary commands, it's never going to end well.

Liran Tal

ğŸš€ Â Coming Soon: Fixed-Cost Monthly Maintenance by UpgradeJS.com â€” Too much tech debt in your JavaScript app? Let us help. Slow and steady upgrades at your own pace. Releasing nextÂ week.

ğŸŒ³ Bonsai by UpgradeJS.com sponsor

ğŸ§­ Â What's New in Safari 17 â€” Safari 17 is now in beta on iOS 17 with the final release dropping across all of Appleâ€™s platforms next week. On the JavaScript front, Safari and WebKit now fully support the Storage API, WebGL in Offscreen Canvas, v flag support on regexes, Set operation methods, URL.canParse, plus the much anticipated support for PWAs in macOSÂ Sonoma.

Jen Simmons and the WebKit team

Testing Out the Alpine.js Intersect Plugin â€” A wrapper for the Intersection ObserverÂ API.
Raymond Camden

â–¶Â Â How to Make Forms in Angular Reusable
Decoded Frontend

Clean Layout Architecture for Vue Applications
Fotis Adamakis

Incremental Static Regeneration for Angular
Enea Jahollari

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

fx 30: The Go(lang)-Powered Terminal JSONÂ Viewer â€” Yes, it's written in Go, but fx has long been a useful tool for looking at JSON files, and it has just been rewritten from the ground up with a new look, regex search, fuzzy search, and support for â€œeven the most massive JSON files.â€ You don't need to worry about Go at all; it's simply a fantastic tool for looking atÂ JSON.

Anton Medvedev

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, andÂ more.

Wallaby.js sponsor

Mantine 7.0: The Popular React Component Library â€” A big release for what is now one of the most popular React component libraries. As of v7, Mantine no longer relies on Emotion and components come with native CSS files, all components now support the system-set color scheme, CSS modules are now the default way to style components, and there are many smaller enhancementsÂ too.

Mantine Team

Chrono 2.7: A Natural Language Date Parser â€” Give it a string like â€œtodayâ€, â€œlast Fridayâ€, â€œ2 weeks from nowâ€, or even an entire date and time, and itâ€™ll come up with a date object toÂ suit.

Wanasit Tanakitrungruang

Theatre.js 0.7: Motion Design for the Web â€” Can be used both programmatically or via a visual editor to animate objects created with things like Three.js, React Three Fiber, HTML/SVG, or even just tween variableÂ values.

Theatre.js Project

Track Errors and Performance Issues in Every Part of Your Stack

Sentry sponsor

Swup: A Flexible Page Transition Library for Server-Side RenderedÂ Sites â€” A library that benefits hugely from checking out the demos. v4.4 adds experimental ViewTransition support.

Georgy Marchuk

Create Chrome Extension: A Scaffolding Tool for Chrome Extensions â€” Similar to create-react-app or Yeoman, this is specifically for starting extension development, with support for several frameworks, HMR, and light/darkÂ modes.

Yalda

ğŸ’¡ Chrome Extension CLI is another option in this space.

  • Neutralinojs 4.14.0 â€“Â Imagine something like Electron but without the browser engine being bundled in. Supporting Linux, Windows, and macOS, it instead leans on what's alreadyÂ present.

  • ğŸ“… React Lite Month Picker
    â†³ An elegant way to let users select a specific month.

  • React-Virtuoso 4.6 â€“ Powerful virtual list component.

  • Faker 8.1 â€“ Generate large amounts of fake data.

  • ğŸ”Š Peaks.js 3.1
    â†³ The BBC's audio waveform UI component.

  • Ember.js 5.3

ğŸ’» Jobs

Nest.js Back-End Developer â€” Lead the development of a HealthTech platform, focused on Caregiver support. TypeScript, Nest.js, PostgreSQL, AWS,Â React/Next.js.
Carallel

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

â€œThe best programs are the ones written when the programmer is supposed to be working on something else.â€

___
Melinda Varian

items.title: JavaScript, ML and LLMs
items.content:
#â€‹654 â€” September 14, 2023

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Bun 1.0: Is It a Toolkit? Is It a Runtime? It's Both â€” Youâ€™ve used Node, youâ€™ve seen Deno, now Bun has grown up too. Itâ€™s a performance-oriented server-side JS runtime built atop JavaScriptCore and makes the unique claim of being â€œa drop-in replacement for Node.js.â€ It includes extras like transpilation, bundling, package management, and a Jest-compatible test runner too. The post goes into a lot of depth, but we enjoyed the Bun teamâ€™s â–¶ï¸ 10 minute introductory video. Does Bun deliver on all its promises yet? No. Is it promising? Yes.

Jarred Sumner et al.

Why Does every() Return true for Empty Arrays? â€” Nicholas wondered how a condition can possibly be satisfied when there arenâ€™t any values to test, so he dug into the language specs to understand theÂ logic.

Nicholas C. Zakas

The Complete UI Component Library For Enterprise Web Apps â€” A professional UI component library with power widgets like data grid, calendar, scheduler & Gantt charts. Includes API docs, guides and an unreasonable amount of demos to play with. Seamlessly integrates with React, Angular, Vue & SalesforceÂ apps.

Bryntum sponsor

A First Look at TypeScript 5.3 â€” TypeScript 5.2 landed a few weeks ago, which means TypeScript 5.3 is already in the works (the final release is due in November), with possible features to think about including Import Attributes, throw expressions, and isolatedÂ declarations.

Matt Pocock

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ“… ViteConf is taking place this October 5-6. It's free and online.

  • The August 2023 build of VS Code has just been released and includes improvements to the JS debugger including WebAssembly module decompilation, as well as Move to File and Inline Variable refactorings.

  • Linus Groh is working on a JavaScript engine in Zig called Kiesel, mostly as a learning project, but it's passing 25% of test262 after four months of effort.

  • While searching for something else, I encountered this JavaScript tutorial from 1996 that's still online. Amazingly, most of it still works fine today.

  • Esteemed Microsoft code archaeologist Raymond Chen looks at how freestanding JS functions using this can be mistaken for a constructor by VS Codeâ€™s static analyzer.

ğŸ‰ RELEASES:

  • MikroORM 5.8 â€“ Powerful Node.js ORM.

  • Reason 3.10 â€“ Write code in OCaml, but for the JS ecosystem.

  • Happy DOM 11.0 â€“ A JS implementation of a web browser sans UI.

  • Node.js v20.6.1 (Current)

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

JavaScript's New Array Grouping Methods â€” A look at Object.groupBy and Map.groupBy. The proposal including these methods is currently at stage 3 at TC39, but initial support is creeping into dev builds of browsers.

Phil Nash

JPEG and EXIF Data Manipulation in JavaScript â€” A look at how to pick through the JPEG format and read and replace EXIF tags directly without leaning on a third partyÂ library.

CÃ©dric Patchane

Frontend Performance Monitoring 101 â€” Learn the basics of JavaScript application performance monitoring to see (and fix) slow faster. Join us for aÂ liveÂ AMA.

Sentry sponsor

â–¶Â Â Building a Mario Game Complete with Auth and Score Saving â€” Ania tackles the implementation of a game in her usual thorough, step-by-stepÂ manner.

Ania KubÃ³w

Running a Playwright Script on AWS Lambda â€” If youâ€™ve struggled to make it work too, Matt has someÂ pointers.

Matt Steele

A New Method to Validate URLs â€” URL.canParse isnâ€™t broadly supported yet, but can be easilyÂ polyfilled.

Stefan Judis

How to Run a GitHub Gist with npx â€” This is an interesting way to quickly deploy a script.

Kelly Fox

ğŸ•‘ Lei Mao has a cute example of using React in an ad-hoc way on a web page to dynamically render an analog clock. No build step. No JSX.

â–¶ï¸ Jack Herrington refutes six reasons not to use React.

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Shadcn for Vue: Components You Can Copy and Paste â€” A community-led Vue port of the React-oriented shadcn/ui, a suite of attractive components built with Tailwind CSS and Radix UI, thus making them easy to â€˜copy and pasteâ€™ into your ownÂ apps.

Radix Vue Project

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript Datagrid

Wijmo from GrapeCity sponsor

npm-check-updates: Update package.json Dependencies to LatestÂ Versions â€” That is, as opposed to the specified versions. It include a handy -i interactive mode so you can look at potential upgrades and then opt in to them one byÂ one.

Raine Revere

Starry Night 3.0: GitHub-Like Syntax Highlighting â€” GitHubâ€™s own syntax highlighter isnâ€™t open source, but Starry Night uses WebAssembly (to get access to the Oniguruma regex engine) to get as close as itÂ can.

Titus Wormer

Vuestic 1.8: Open Source UI Library for Vue 3 â€” A library of more than 60 customizable components. v1.8 introduces new Layout and Textarea components. OfficialÂ homepage.

Epicmax

Goxygen 0.7: Quickly Generate a Go Backend for a JS Project â€” A tool that sets up a new Go-based project with Angular, React, or Vue in the front-end, and Docker and Docker Compose files to make it allÂ work.

Sasha Shpota

Deliver Real-Time Live Streams with Amazon IVS â€” Amazon IVS enables developers to create dynamic real-time and low-latency video experiences. ClickÂ here to learnÂ more.

Amazon Web Services (AWS) sponsor

xterm.js 5.3.0: Build Terminals in the Browser â€” Itâ€™s used in many projects like VS Code, cPanel, Azure Cloud Shell, and other browser-based IDEs. Thereâ€™s a live demo on the homepage toÂ try.

xterm.js team

  • Gridstack.js 9.2
    â†³ Build interactive dashboards in minutes. (Demos.)

  • Accessible Astro Starter 3.0
    â†³ A starter theme for an Astro-powered blog.

  • Ant Design 5.9
    â†³ Popular React UI library & design language.

  • ğŸ“Š Reveal.js 4.6 â€“ Write presentations in HTML.

  • Electron 26.2

ğŸ’» Jobs

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Hired makes job hunting easy-instead of chasing recruiters, companies approach you with salary details up front. Create a free profileÂ now.
Hired

ğŸ¤–Â A little JavaScript AI-side..

AI, LLMs and machine learning have caught the imagination of many developers recently, whether through training and deploying models, calling out to third party APIs (like those OpenAI offers), or using tools like GitHub Copilot to write code. It's common, however, for a lot of AI/LLM experimentation to take place in Python, rather than JavaScript..

Nonetheless, there's an increasing number of projects in the JavaScript AI/ML space worth keeping an eye on, as well as an upcoming AI developer event being organized by two folks from the JavaScript space:

Transformers.js: State-of-the-Art Machine Learning for the Web â€” A JavaScript library designed to be functionally equivalent to Hugging Faceâ€™s transformers Python library meaning you can run the same pretrained models using a very similar API. You can do things like ML-powered speech recognition directly in your browser using OpenAIâ€™s Whisper model. GitHubÂ repo.

Joshua Lochner et al.

Microsoft TypeChat: An Approach for Type-Safe LLM Responses â€” Anders Hejlsberg and Daniel Rosenwasser of TypeScript fame are just two of the prominent names attached to this project, demonstrating the huge interest within MS for LLMs. TypeChatâ€™s goal is to work around the issue of LLMs outputting unstructured natural language and to direct output into a typed form.

Hejlsberg, Lucco, Rosenwasser et al.

WebLLM: Run LLM Models in the Browser with WebGPU â€” Less directly JavaScript, as it uses WebGPU, but yet another way to run large language models directly within the browser and that you can control from JavaScript. GitHubÂ repo.

MLC LLM

TensorFlow.js: Machine Learning for JavaScript Developers â€” Slightly lower level, but a great way to train and deploy models in the browser or in Node.js. There are, of course, lots of demos, too.

TensorFlow

JavaScript Library Lets Devs Add AI Capabilities to the Web
Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

â–¶Â Â A Primer on AI for Developers with Swyx from Latent Space
Svelte Radio

ğŸ“… Plus, two JavaScript folks are putting on an AI event..

As part of my interest in AI and ML, I'm attending what promises to be the technical AI event of the year in San Francisco next month: The AI EngineerÂ Summit.

The emerging 'AI engineer' category is at the intersection of AI/ML and code: where software engineers can access and implement powerful AI models with just an API. Andrej Karpathy believes that "there's probably going to be significantly more AI engineers than there are ML engineers / LLM engineers."

With speakers representing companies like OpenAI, Microsoft, Replit, Vercel, AutoGPT, Adept, LlamaIndex, and Notion, at the Hotel Nikko this October 8-10, the event is organized by two folks well known in our space: Swyx (who you may remember from his popular The Third Age of JavaScript post) and Benjamin Dunphy, formerly of Reactathon and Jamstack Conf. You can apply to attend or get a free remote ticket to tune in from wherever you are.

If you're going to the AI Engineer Summit, I'll see you there!

ğŸ‘‹

ğŸ¤–Â A little JavaScript AI-side..




AI, LLMs and machine learning have caught the imagination of many developers recently, whether through training and deploying models, calling out to third party APIs (like those OpenAI offers), or using tools like GitHub Copilot to write code. It's common, however, for a lot of AI/LLM experimentation to take place in Python, rather than JavaScript..
Nonetheless, there's an increasing number of projects in the JavaScript AI/ML space worth keeping an eye on, as well as an upcoming AI developer event being organized by two folks from the JavaScript space:


  
  
Transformers.js: State-of-the-Art Machine Learning for the Web â€” A JavaScript library designed to be functionally equivalent to Hugging Faceâ€™s transformers Python library meaning you can run the same pretrained models using a very similar API. You can do things like ML-powered speech recognition directly in your browser using OpenAIâ€™s Whisper model. GitHubÂ repo.
Joshua Lochner et al. 


  
  
Microsoft TypeChat: An Approach for Type-Safe LLM Responses â€” Anders Hejlsberg and Daniel Rosenwasser of TypeScript fame are just two of the prominent names attached to this project, demonstrating the huge interest within MS for LLMs. TypeChatâ€™s goal is to work around the issue of LLMs outputting unstructured natural language and to direct output into a typed form.
Hejlsberg, Lucco, Rosenwasser et al. 


  
  
WebLLM: Run LLM Models in the Browser with WebGPU â€” Less directly JavaScript, as it uses WebGPU, but yet another way to run large language models directly within the browser and that you can control from JavaScript. GitHubÂ repo.
MLC LLM 


  
  
TensorFlow.js: Machine Learning for JavaScript Developers â€” Slightly lower level, but a great way to train and deploy models in the browser or in Node.js. There are, of course, lots of demos, too.
TensorFlow 


  
JavaScript Library Lets Devs Add AI Capabilities to the Web

ğŸ“… Plus, two JavaScript folks are putting on an AI event..
As part of my interest in AI and ML, I'm attending what promises to be the technical AI event of the year in San Francisco next month: The AI EngineerÂ Summit.
The emerging 'AI engineer' category is at the intersection of AI/ML and code: where software engineers can access and implement powerful AI models with just an API. Andrej Karpathy believes that "there's probably going to be significantly more AI engineers than there are ML engineers / LLM engineers."
With speakers representing companies like OpenAI, Microsoft, Replit, Vercel, AutoGPT, Adept, LlamaIndex, and Notion, at the Hotel Nikko this October 8-10, the event is organized by two folks well known in our space: Swyx (who you may remember from his popular The Third Age of JavaScript post) and Benjamin Dunphy, formerly of Reactathon and Jamstack Conf. You can apply to attend or get a free remote ticket to tune in from wherever you are.
If you're going to the AI Engineer Summit, I'll see you there!
